title: Pathological line-limit interaction with scope opening
body:
Original:
```scala
  private def run(implicit S: ScheduledExecutorService): Process[Task, Unit] = {
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
  private def run(implicit S: ScheduledExecutorService): Process[Task, Unit] =
    {
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
  private def run(implicit S: ScheduledExecutorService): Process[Task, Unit] = {
```

Using:
* 0.2.6-RC1
* --style default --maxColumn 80

So, the problem here is that the original input is exactly 81 characters in length.  Scalafmt penalizes this and decides to bump the whole scope to the next line, extra indented.  This makes sense as a general rule, but here it's definitely not the right approach.  A line length overflow of 1 character should not cause the *entire* function body to get indented another level.

title: More robust/standard configuration
body:
Following discussions on Gitter: https://gitter.im/olafurpg/scalafmt?at=5755e80492fc7c915f574b06

The current configuration is built on scopt and is quite hacky: https://olafurpg.github.io/scalafmt/#Configuration
It would be great to use a more standard syntax.

Requirements:
* Scala.js compatible
* supports comments
* not verbose
* allows multiple configurations on same line, like `a=1;b=2`. See #315

Considered options:
* [shocon](https://github.com/unicredit/shocon) seems like a perfect fit. @andreaTP, are there any docs/non-SNAPSHOT releases?
* typesafe config: no Scala.js support.
* http://oncue.github.io/knobs/: can't see Scala.js support.
* YAML: Don't think there's any Scala.js implementation.

title: Feature request: Dynamic style configuration
body:
Dynamic style configuration allows you to change the style with CLI flags inside comments. For example, increase `--maxColumn` or temporarily enable vertical alignment.

Original:
```scala
val x = 1
val xx = 2
// --style defaultWithAlign
val xxx  = 3
val xxxx = 4
// --style default
val xxxxx = 5
val xxxxxx = 6
```

title: Correct all other mentions of "paretheses"
body: I didn't realise the mistake was repeated.

title: Abstract type constructor spuriously "spaced out"
body:
Original:
```scala
type F[A]
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
type F [A]  // ??????
```

Question marks may have been added by me…

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
type F[A]
```

Ideally, scalafmt would actually *remove* spacing in this case if it is present.  I can't think of anyone who prefers a formatting style which injects spaces in this case.

title: 2.6.0-RC1 formatting issue
body:
Original (2.5.0):
```scala
    CreditCard(customerId = customerId,
               gatewayCustomerId = sCust.getId,
               gatewayCardId = card.getId,
               holderName = p.holderName,
               lastFour = p.lastFour,
               expMonth = p.expMonth,
               expYear = p.expYear,
               isDefault = p.isDefault,
               address1Check = card.getAddressLine1Check.some,
               zipCheck = card.getAddressZipCheck.some,
               regionId = a.regionId,
               addressName = a.name,
               address1 = a.address1,
               address2 = a.address2,
               city = a.city,
               zip = a.zip,
               brand = card.getBrand)
```

Scalafmt 2.6.0-RC1:
```scala
    CreditCard(
        customerId =
          customerId,
        gatewayCustomerId =
          sCust.getId,
        gatewayCardId = card.getId,
        holderName = p.holderName,
        lastFour = p.lastFour,
        expMonth =
          p.expMonth,
        expYear = p.expYear,
        isDefault = p.isDefault,
               address1Check = card.getAddressLine1Check.some,
               zipCheck = card.getAddressZipCheck.some,
               regionId = a.regionId,
               addressName = a.name,
               address1 = a.address1,
               address2 = a.address2,
               city = a.city,
               zip = a.zip,
               brand = card.getBrand)
```

Using:
```
$ cat .scalafmt                                                                                                                                    *[bump-scalafmt] 
--style defaultWithAlign
--maxColumn 100
# --spaceAfterTripleEquals true
```

I know it's not a release bug, but just so you know stuff's broken.

title: CLI: add flag to print out build info
body:
A flag like `--build-info` that would print out data such as

* which commit (if any) the CLI was built at
* build timestamp
* build OS (if relevant)

I could use the [build info sbt plugin](https://github.com/sbt/sbt-buildinfo) or I could implement it myself with a macro.

title: the formatted results diff between scalafmt plugin in intellij and cli
not any output when applying scalafmt to specified scala file
New feature request: explicit types
body:
I recently ran into a user transitioning from Java who found some Scala code harder to read and maintain because of the implicit types. He wants the ability to make the types explicit using some tool. One person suggested "It's probably easier to add this [feature] to scalafmt, which uses scala.meta to format code. It wouldn't be too difficult to use scala.meta to get the type an expression and add it if it missing."

What do you think?

title: {} of method body ejected on the next line
Enable sorting imports within braces
body:
Original:
```scala
import foo.{Zilch, bar, Random, sand}
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
import foo.{bar, sand, Random, Zilch}
```

----

While scalafmt clearly cannot reorder general import statements due to hierarchical import semantics, those semantics do not apply within braces as shown, so reordering is valid.

I can see two valid rules here:

- Alphabetical, with lower-case grouped
- Strictly alphabetical

I like the first option, and this seems to be relatively uncontroversial, but I can imagine some people prefer the second.  The first option is demonstrated above.  The second option would yield the following:

```scala
import foo.{bar, Random, sand, Zilch}
```

body: Or alternatively, RC1.  Version 0.2.5 doesn't have the settings that I really need to use scalafmt, but master does.  If you could just do a quick publish on the RC (any RC) to sonatype, that would help me immensely!

title: Automatically reformat files after an active editing session
body:
Interesting suggestion from @djspiewak in #295. I can see this being an incredibly useful feature. Question is whether this should belong in the SBT plugin or in the text editor integrations as some sort of "reformat on unfocus" action.

My problem with implementing this as part of the SBT plugin is:
1. It's limited to text editors that create swap files in the same directory as the file. For example, I set my vim to put the swap files in `/tmp` and IntelliJ doesn't leave any swap files.
2. It would be tricky to get right since the current `reformatOnCompileSettings` implementation taps into the incremental compiler to know which files to format. The SBT plugin would need to know when the swap file is removed to know that it should reformat the source file.

By integrating this directly, I imagine the user experience would be smoother. However, if someone wants to take a stab at this in the SBT plugin, the relevant line of code is here: https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/blob/6adefe05cc43c914569e181c1061153dafd88528/scalafmtSbt/src/main/scala/org/scalafmt/sbt/HasScalaFmt.scala#L46

body: I was struggling with making scalafmt work on IT sources, and I think a piece of configuration might be missing from the plugin. I wonder if `configScalafmtSettings` should be defined for `IntegrationTest` as well as for `Compile` and `Test` [here] (https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/blob/a61bd6244b1982556ddcab7180e848ead893bedf/scalafmtSbt/src/main/scala/org/scalafmt/sbt/ScalaFmtPlugin.scala#L50-L52).

title: scalafmt creates huge diffs?
body:
I read this http://olafurpg.github.io/scalafmt/#scalafmtcreateshugediffs!, and wonder, is this something we must expect most of the time when comitting changes to Scala code?
I understand that there will be lots of diffs the first time scalafmt does reformatting, but why should there be huge diffs later on?

title: Scala files in test folder ignored by reformatOnCompileSettings
body:
I'm testing scalafmt on a project where the top level folders are app, conf, lib, project, public, target and test. In sbt I'm running `~ compile`, and each time I edit and save a .scala file within the app folder, the file gets reformatted, as expected. However, when I edit and save a .scala file within the test folder, no reformatting occurs. Is this a bug or a feature?

Using:
* 0.2.5
* --style default
* --maxColumn 100

title: scalafmtConfig, Type error in expression
body:
Hi,

I'm quite new to Scala, but I wanted to try your scalafmt as an sbt plugin. I installed scalafmt using homebrew, and I got scalafmt 0.2.5. Then I cloned your sbt-scalafmt-example, but when I do `sbt scalafmt`, I get this:
```
Loading /Users/jkleiser/bin/sbt/bin/sbt-launch-lib.bash
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: ignoring option MaxPermSize=256m; support was removed in 8.0
[info] Loading project definition from /Volumes/P3/Scala/sbt-scalafmt-example/project
/Volumes/P3/Scala/sbt-scalafmt-example/build.sbt:1: error: not found: value scalafmtConfig
scalafmtConfig := Some(file(".scalafmt"))
^
[error] Type error in expression
```

Using:
* 0.2.5

* --maxColumn 40

What's can be wrong in my setup?

title: Issue linter warnings
body:
This issue is to open up a discussion on whether scalafmt should also issue warnings alongside formatting code. This could be as simple as adding a `warnings: Seq[Warning]` member to [FormatResult.Success](https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/blob/cb663557e207f04f8b164ca86eb2af119c6f6ca3/core/src/main/scala/org/scalafmt/FormatResult.scala#L15).

I have received several suggestions online and offline about this. One example is #281. I also believe scalafmt could emit useful warnings about possible code smells (when the search state explodes as in #278).

title: =;Term.Arg false positives
body:
Original:
```scala
    Summary(
      ts       = Option(genFunc),
      t        = Option(genFunc),
      p        = Option(genFunc),
      m        = Option(genFunc),
      s        = Option(genFunc),
      tb       = Option(genFunc)
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
Summary( 
       ts = Option(genFunc),
        t = Option(genFunc),
        p = Option(genFunc),
        m = Option(genFunc),
        s = Option(genFunc),
        tb = Option(genFunc)
)
```

Token alignment falls apart for multiline parameters. From the above, running scalafmt will reset the spacing of any parameter assignment.
It seems that token alignment shouldn't matter whether or not it is for parameters or not, so I was hoping that scalafmt would produce this kind of output:

```scala
    Summary(
      ts       = Option(genFunc),
      t        = Option(genFunc),
      p        = Option(genFunc),
      m        = Option(genFunc),
      s        = Option(genFunc),
      t        = Option(genFunc)
)
```

Using:
* 0.2.5
* --style defaultWithAlign

title: Strange abstract type constructor reformatting
body:
Original:
```scala
trait Foo[F[_]] {
  type G[A]
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
trait Foo[F[_]] {
  type G [A]
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
trait Foo[F[_]] {
  type G[A]
```

Using:
* master

```
--maxColumn 100
# --binPackArguments false
# --binPackParameters false
# --binPackDotChains false
--continuationIndentCallSite 2
--allowNewlineBeforeColonInMassiveReturnTypes false
--binPackParentConstructors false
--alignByArrowEnumeratorGenerator false
```

title: Expose --alignByArrowEnumeratorGenerator in CLI
body: I think I did this right?

title: Add alignByArrowEnumeratorGenerator to CLI flags
body: Currently `alignByArrowEnumeratorGenerator` is part of [ScalafmtStyle](https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/blob/10b78abb5cc0a68e1be41ba50e85772967334cae/core/src/main/scala/org/scalafmt/ScalafmtStyle.scala#L43) but not the CLI.

title: Add flag --danglingParentheses
body:
Original:
```scala
function(
  longerArg1,
  longerArg2,
  longerArg3)
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
function(
  longerArg1,
  longerArg2,
  longerArg3)
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
function(
  longerArg1,
  longerArg2,
  longerArg3
)
```

Using:
* 0.2.5

```scala
style = ScalafmtStyle.default.copy(
  maxColumn = 10,
  continuationIndentCallSite = 2,
  continuationIndentDefnSite = 2,
  configStyleArguments = true
)
```

Oddly enough it seems to do what I want in some cases:

```scala
haoyi-Ammonite@ org.scalafmt.Scalafmt.format(
                       """html(
                  head(
                    script(src:="..."),
                    script(
                      "alert('Hello World')"
                    )
                  ),
                  body(
                    div(
                      h1(id:="title", "This is a title"),
                      p("This is a big paragraph of text")
                    )
                  )
                )""".replace(" ", ""),
                       style = ScalafmtStyle.default.copy(
                         maxColumn = 50,
                         continuationIndentCallSite = 2,
                         continuationIndentDefnSite = 2,
                         configStyleArguments = true
                       ),
                       runner = ScalafmtRunner.statement
                     ).get
res11: String = """
html(
  head(
    script(src := "..."),
    script(
      "alert('HelloWorld')"
    )
  ),
  body(
    div(
      h1(id := "title", "Thisisatitle"),
      p("Thisisabigparagraphoftext")
    )
  )
)

"""
```

But not others:

```scala
haoyi-Ammonite@ org.scalafmt.Scalafmt.format(
                       """html(fooooooooooooooooooooooo, barrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr

                )""".replace(" ", ""),
                       style = ScalafmtStyle.default.copy(
                         maxColumn = 50,
                         continuationIndentCallSite = 2,
                         continuationIndentDefnSite = 2,
                         configStyleArguments = true
                       ),
                       runner = ScalafmtRunner.statement
                     ).get
res12: String = """
html(fooooooooooooooooooooooo,
     barrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr)

"""
```

Given `configStyleArguments = true`, I want any multi-line parens to *always* have the closing paren on a new-line, java-curly-style, as opposed to having it tacked on the end of an existing line list-style

title: Infix operators should stay the same v2
body:
Thanks for putting this tool together. I noticed this quirk and wasn't sure if it was intentional:

Original:
```scala
  private[reports] def headerText(colBarcodes: Seq[String], compat: Boolean): String = {
    s"Sequence\tTotal\t${colBarcodes.mkString("\t")}\t" +
    (if (compat) "Construct IDs" else "Potential IDs")
  }
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
  private[reports] def headerText(colBarcodes: Seq[String], compat: Boolean): String = {
    s"Sequence\tTotal\t${colBarcodes.mkString("\t")}\t" + (if (compat) "Construct IDs" else "Potential IDs")
  }
```

I'm not sure my original formatting is the ideal solution in this case; however it seems that scalafmt should respect the `--maxColumns` setting rather than removing the line break after the `+` operator.
```scala
  private[reports] def headerText(colBarcodes: Seq[String], compat: Boolean): String = {
    s"Sequence\tTotal\t${colBarcodes.mkString("\t")}\t" +
    (if (compat) "Construct IDs" else "Potential IDs")
  }
```

Using:
* 0.2.5
* --style default

I ran the transformation using the IntelliJ plugin, but I doubt that's relevant. My .scalafmt:
```
-s default
--allowNewlineBeforeColonInMassiveReturnTypes false
--maxColumn 120
```

title: Preserve final empty line inside functions
body:
Original:
```scala
def heyImCool = {

  val a = foo
  val b = bar(a)

  val c = b.foobar

}
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
def heyImCool = {

  val a = foo
  val b = bar(a)

  val c = b.foobar
}
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
def heyImCool = {

  val a = foo
  val b = bar(a)

  val c = b.foobar

}
```

Using:
* 0.2.5
* --style default

SBT plugin did not format some files.

```
> scalafmt
```

```
      implicit ec: EC): Foo[Bar[Baz]] =
```

After:

```
      someObject: SomeClass)(implicit ec: EC): Foo[Bar[Baz]] =
```

```
$ cat .scalafmt
--style defaultWithAlign
--maxColumn 100
```

```
$ grep scalafmt build.sbt
scalafmtConfig := Some(file(".scalafmt"))
```

Intellij plugin Version: 0.2.5

title: Suggestions about names
body:
Would be nice if scalafmt could give some advices about naming. It is possible to create a method naming convention, based on [StrategicScalaStyle](http://www.lihaoyi.com/post/StrategicScalaStyleConcisenessNames.html)-like guides. Some of those guidelines can be checked statistically for given project.

This might be out of scope for scalafmt, because no reasonable autocorrection exist, and each warning require human attention. However, this might be really useful feature.

title: Empty "bad files" in FormatExperiment
body: [This list](https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/blob/0f7a86e27795a50783df97f909a3bab94630273b/core/src/test/scala/org/scalafmt/FormatExperiment.scala#L38)

title: scalafmt is not idempotent for this example
body:
Using settings: 
--maxColumn 140

Original:
```scala
trait SelfEmploymentsBalancingChargesController extends BaseController with Links {

  val balancingChargesJson = toJson(
    balancingCharges.map(balancingCharge =>
      halResource(
        obj(),
        Seq(HalLink("self",
          selfEmploymentSummaryTypeIdHref(saUtr, taxYear, seId, BalancingChargesSummaryType, balancingCharge.id.get))))))
}

```

Scalafmt:
```scala
trait SelfEmploymentsBalancingChargesController extends BaseController with Links {

  val balancingChargesJson = toJson(
      balancingCharges.map(balancingCharge =>
            halResource(obj(),
                        Seq(HalLink("self",
                                    selfEmploymentSummaryTypeIdHref(
                                        saUtr, taxYear, seId, BalancingChargesSummaryType, balancingCharge.id.get))))))
}
```

When applying the formatter repeatedly the output varies between:
```scala
trait SelfEmploymentsBalancingChargesController extends BaseController with Links {

  val balancingChargesJson = toJson(
      balancingCharges.map(balancingCharge =>
            halResource(
                obj(),
                Seq(HalLink("self",
                            selfEmploymentSummaryTypeIdHref(saUtr, taxYear, seId, BalancingChargesSummaryType, balancingCharge.id.get))))))
}

```
and

```scala
trait SelfEmploymentsBalancingChargesController extends BaseController with Links {

  val balancingChargesJson = toJson(
      balancingCharges.map(balancingCharge =>
            halResource(obj(),
                        Seq(HalLink("self",
                                    selfEmploymentSummaryTypeIdHref(
                                        saUtr, taxYear, seId, BalancingChargesSummaryType, balancingCharge.id.get))))))
}
```

Using
* 0.2.5

title: Option to insert unicode arrows
body:
Scalariform has an option "RewriteArrowSymbols". It replaces => with ⇒, etc. 

I'd like an equivalent in scalafmt.

title: Alignment in case class `extends`
body:
Original:
```scala
final case class Manifest(
    name: String,
    schemaVersion: Int = 1
) extends SchemaManifest
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
final case class Manifest(
    name: String,
    schemaVersion: Int = 1
)
    extends SchemaManifest
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
case class Manifest(
       name: String,
       schemaVersion: Int = 1
    )
    extends SchemaManifest
```

Using
* 0.2.5

title: Qualified super

```scala
   override def fillInStackTrace(): Throwable =
-    super[Error].fillInStackTrace()
+    super [Error].fillInStackTrace()
```

```scala
     @inline def rawToInt(x: Double): Int =
-      (x.asInstanceOf[js.Dynamic] | 0.asInstanceOf[js.Dynamic]).asInstanceOf[Int]
+      (x.asInstanceOf[js.Dynamic] | 0.asInstanceOf[js.Dynamic]).asInstanceOf[
```

title: Prune slow states
body:
Original:
```scala
-        val newQuot = inline_+(quotLo, quotHi,
-            unsignedSafeDoubleLo(rem_div_bDouble),
+        val newQuot = inline_+(quotLo,
+            quotHi, unsignedSafeDoubleLo(rem_div_bDouble),
```

title: Binary operator precedence and spaces
body:
Original:
```scala
-    if (iv == value && 1.0/value != Double.NegativeInfinity) iv
+    if (iv == value && 1.0 / value != Double.NegativeInfinity) iv
```
See https://github.com/scala-js/scala-js/blob/master/CODINGSTYLE.md#spaces

title: } else
Attached comment
body:
Original:
```scala
-  private class Encoder extends CharsetEncoder(
-      UTF_16_Common.this, 2.0f, 2.0f,
-      // Character 0xfffd
-      if (endianness == LittleEndian) Array(-3, -1) else Array(-1, -3)) {
+  private class Encoder
+      extends CharsetEncoder(UTF_16_Common.this, 2.0f,
+          2.0f, // Character 0xfffd
+          if (endianness == LittleEndian) Array(-3, -1) else Array(-1, -3)) {
```

title: New-line in assignment
body:
Original:
```scala
-                val ps = params map { p =>
-                  JSMethodParam(p.info, p.asTerm.isParamWithDefault)
-                }
+                val ps =
+                  params map { p =>
+                    JSMethodParam(p.info, p.asTerm.isParamWithDefault)
+                  }
```

title: Vertical alignment in Scala.js style only for =>;Case
body:
Original:
```scala
   def unwrapJavaScriptException(th: Throwable): Any = th match {
     case js.JavaScriptException(e) => e
-    case _                         => th
+    case _ => th
   }
```

title: (Chains of) infix applications
body:
Original:
```scala
        params.size >= thatParams.size &&
        resultType <:< thatResultType &&
        unused.forall(_.isDefault) &&
        (used zip thatParams).forall { case (x, y) => x.conformsTo(y) }
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
        params.size >= thatParams.size && resultType <:< thatResultType &&
        unused.forall(_.isDefault) && (used zip thatParams).forall {
          case (x, y) => x.conformsTo(y)
        }
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
        params.size >= thatParams.size &&
        resultType <:< thatResultType &&
        unused.forall(_.isDefault) &&
        (used zip thatParams).forall {
          case (x, y) => x.conformsTo(y)
        }
```

Although, if there was `()` around an inner `&&`, I'd like for example:
```scala
        (params.size >= thatParams.size && resultType <:< thatResultType) &&
        unused.forall(_.isDefault) &&
        (used zip thatParams).forall {
          case (x, y) => x.conformsTo(y)
        }
```

Using
* 0.1.x

title: New property: optimizations do not change formatting output
body:
Something like:
```scala
format(code, optimizations=true) == format(code, optimzations=false)
```

title: Fix ExperimentApp for scala.js style
body:
I manually ran ExperimentApp with --style Scala.js and found lots of breaking cases. A good idea would be to use [Travis parallel build features](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/speeding-up-the-build/#Parallelizing-your-builds-across-virtual-machines) to run scala.js and default style.

```scala
 ScalaFile(
```

title: Space after private[scope]
Annotation before val

Original:
```scala
 @native
 sealed trait Tuple2[+T1, +T2] extends Object {
-  @JSName("0") val _1: T1 = native
-  @JSName("1") val _2: T2 = native
+  @JSName("0")
```

title: Blocks escaping indentation laws
body:
Original:
```scala
      val p2 = scala.concurrent.Promise[A]()
      p.`then`[Unit](
          { (v: A) =>
            p2.success(v)
            (): Unit | Thenable[Unit]
          },
          defined { (e: scala.Any) =>
            p2.failure(e match {
              case th: Throwable => th
              case _             => JavaScriptException(e)
            })
            (): Unit | Thenable[Unit]
          })
      p2.future
```
Scalafmt:
```scala
      val p2 = scala.concurrent.Promise[A]()
      p.`then`[Unit]({ (v: A) =>
        p2.success(v)
        (): Unit | Thenable[Unit]
      },
      defined { (e: scala.Any) =>
        p2.failure(e match {
              case th: Throwable => th
              case _ => JavaScriptException(e)
            })
        (): Unit | Thenable[Unit]
      })
      p2.future
```
Want: the original

```scala
-class Promise[+A](
-    executor: js.Function2[js.Function1[A | Thenable[A], _], js.Function1[scala.Any, _], _])
+class Promise[+A](executor: js.Function2[js.Function1[A | Thenable[A], _],
+    js.Function1[scala.Any, _], _])
     extends js.Object with js.Thenable[A] {
```

```scala
  @inline
  def apply(
  body: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      dir: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      icon: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      lang: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      noscreen: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      renotify: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      silent: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      sound: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      sticky: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      tag: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      onclick: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      onerror: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      vibrate: js.UndefOr[js.Array[Double]] =
        js.undefined
        ): NotificationOptions = {
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
  @inline
  def apply(body: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      dir: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      icon: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      lang: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      noscreen: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      renotify: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      silent: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,

      tag: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      onclick: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      onerror: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      vibrate: js.UndefOr[js.Array[Double]] =
        js.undefined): NotificationOptions = {
```

I would like the input to look like this:
```scala
  @inline
  def apply(
      body: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      dir: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      icon: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      lang: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      noscreen: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      renotify: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      silent: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      sound: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      sticky: js.UndefOr[Boolean] = js.undefined,
      tag: js.UndefOr[String] = js.undefined,
      onclick: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      onerror: js.UndefOr[js.Function0[Any]] = js.undefined,
      vibrate: js.UndefOr[js.Array[Double]] = js.undefined
  ): NotificationOptions = {
```

Using
* 0.2.5 --Scala.js

https://github.com/olafurpg/scalafmt/issues/239

This will fallback to `.scalafmt` config file in home directory in case of no such file in project directory.

title: Drop %% in addSbtPlugin
body:
Sbt plugins aren't cross built, see:

  * https://github.com/sbt/sbt/blob/v0.13.11/main/src/main/scala/sbt/Defaults.scala#L1948-L1953
  * https://github.com/sbt/sbt/blob/v0.13.11/main/src/main/scala/sbt/Defaults.scala#L899-L900

crossVersion is disabled

title: Diff formatting

milestone.description: Adds incremental formatting for blazingly fast formatting even on massive source files.

body: Given a diff, format only what has changed. This will also enable incremental formatting in IDEs, giving blazing speed allowing you to format on save.

title: --useDanglingParentheses
body: Similar to scalariform, discussion in #235

title: Configuration: disallow layout 3 in argument list formatting
body:
Original:
```scala
// This is option 3
foobar(a,
      b)
// If we disallow it
foobar(
    a,
    b)
```

I suggest the flag would be named `--alignByOpenApplyParen <value>`.

title: Global configuration for all my projects
body:
My problem is that I have 10s of projects and I don't want to maintain a copy of the .scalafmt file in each project.

The solution can be in machine level (i.e. global .scalafm file) or IntelliJ level (plugin configuration).

title: Exceeding line is not wrapped
body:
Original:
```scala
  private def a012345678901234567(b01234567890123456789: B01234567890123456789): Future[C012345678901[D012345678901]] = {
    ???
  }
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
  private def a012345678901234567(b01234567890123456789: B01234567890123456789): Future[C012345678901[D012345678901]] = {
    ???
  }
```

Actually I don't have a strong preference about how it should look like, provided that the line length doesn't exceed the max 120 characters I provided through the .scalafmt config file:
```
--maxColumn 120
```

Using
* 0.2.3 IntelliJ plugin.

title: Format sbt files

milestone.description: Adds incremental formatting for blazingly fast formatting even on massive source files.

body: scala.meta can now parse sbt files, which means scalafmt should be able to format sbt files.

title: Add bin pack options to CLI flags.
More Configurability
body:
Let's just call this a general desire for significantly more configurability in the formatting style.  Scalariform is a decent example, though it's missing plenty of stuff that I *would* want (line limits being a good example).  I think scalafmt is a far better foundation, but right now its lack of configurability basically prevents me from using it.  :-(

Some general points:

- **Configurability of vertical alignment**  I cannot stress this enough.  Vertical alignment is *not* a universal desire.  I find it almost unreadable (seriously), and while I know I'm in the minority, I'm certainly not the only one.  In general, what I want is the option to make intraline spacing rules context-free (outside of the indentation scope), rather than dependent on contents of the line above/below.
- Dangling parentheses options.  Scalariform is pretty great in this regard, as it allows you to preserve parentheses, force them to their own line (like closing braces), or collapse them to the previous line.
- Better control over parameter blocks linebreaking.  Right now, I believe scalafmt forces a style in which line-broken parameter blocks (actuals and formals) are vertically aligned with the first parameter, which is retained on the same line as the method name.  Some people like this style, while others (like me) would want this situation handled by single-indenting (for actuals) or double-indenting (for formals) and moving all parameters to their own line.

These are just the biggest ones that come to mind.  All in all, I think configurability is by far the most important feature for any formatter.  I understand the desire to be opinionated, but frankly that's a non-starter for a language as syntactically rich as Scala.  Also, I did try to implement this myself, but obviously the way configuration is done right now makes that a rather difficult affair.

Issues:

```scala
 -                              if result.test.name != "Warmup") yield {
```


title: Use unmanagedSourceDirectories for sourceDirectories
body:
`sourceDirectories in hasScalafmt` is currently initialized with
`List(scalaSource.value)` which means that scalafmt only looks into
one source directory per project. But a typical Scala.js cross
project has at least two source directories js/ and shared/ or
jvm/ and shared/. Sometimes there are also multiple source
directories for different Scala versions.

This change initializes `sourceDirectories in hasScalafmt` with
`unmanagedSourceDirectories` which contains all source directories
with manually created sources. In my tests
`unmanagedSourceDirectories` always includes `scalaSource`.

Here are for example both settings for typelevel/cats:

> coreJVM/scalaSource
[info] cats/core/.jvm/src/main/scala

> coreJVM/unmanagedSourceDirectories
[info] List(
  cats/core/.jvm/src/main/scala-2.11,
  cats/core/.jvm/src/main/scala,
  cats/core/.jvm/src/main/java,
  cats/core/src/main/scala)

And since cats has no sources in cats/core/.jvm/src/main/scala,
scalafmt won't format anything.

title: Alignment false positive
body:
Original:
```scala
// from scalafmt
Ok(
    Json.obj(
        "api"                                    -> Json.obj("current" -> api.currentVersion,
                          "olds"                 -> api.oldVersions.map { old =>
                        Json.obj("version"       -> old.version,
                                 "deprecatedAt"  -> old.deprecatedAt,
                                 "unsupportedAt" -> old.unsupportedAt)
                      })
    )) as JSON
// Should be something like this:
   Ok(Json.obj(
       "api" -> Json.obj(
         "current" -> api.currentVersion,
         "olds" -> api.oldVersions.map { old =>
           Json.obj(
             "version" -> old.version,
             "deprecatedAt" -> old.deprecatedAt,
             "unsupportedAt" -> old.unsupportedAt)
         })
     )) as JSON
```

title: Replace "--style scalaJs" flag with "--style scala.js"

milestone.description: Adds incremental formatting for blazingly fast formatting even on massive source files.

body: Or should it be "--style scalajs", any opinions @sjrd?

title: Better chains indentation
broken indent in while condition
body:
Broken test:
```scala
<<< SKIP while condition is like if
    while (!hasReachedEof(curr) &&
    !statementStarts.contains(hash(tokens(curr.splits.length).left))) {
      val tok = tokens(curr.splits.length)
      curr = State.next(curr, style, provided(tok), tok)
    }
>>>
while (!hasReachedEof(curr) &&
       !statementStarts.contains(hash(tokens(curr.splits.length).left))) {
  val tok = tokens(curr.splits.length)
  curr = State.next(curr, style, provided(tok), tok)
}
```

title: Handle Term.Function with Term.Block body
body:
Test:
```scala
        foo.fold(
            err =>
              {
                logger.warn(s"Malformed request: $err\n${req.body}")
                BadRequest(jsonError(JsError toJson err)).fuccess
            },
            data => data)
>>>
foo.fold(err => {
  logger.warn(s"Malformed request: $err\n${req.body}")
  BadRequest(jsonError(JsError toJson err)).fuccess
}, data => data)
```

title: Configuration: disallow layout 2 in argument list formatting
[Feature] keep alignment inside for comprehension (and other constructs?)
If/else consistency
body:
Original:
```scala
    (if (isInterface()) "is interface "
     else if (isPrimitive()) ""
     else "class ") + getName()
```

Scalafmt:
```scala
    (if (isInterface()) "is interface "
     else if (isPrimitive()) "" else "class ") + getName()
```

I would like the input to look like the original

Using
* 0.2.3

title: Fail fast with config error in sbt plugin.
Infix application should stay.
body:
Original:
```scala
@@ -45,9 +46,8 @@ abstract class AbstractSeleniumJSRunner(browserProvider: SeleniumBrowser,
     val inits = initFiles()
 
     val jsFiles = {
-      inits.map(materializer.materialize(_).toString) ++
-      libs.map(dep => materializer.materialize(dep.lib).toString) :+
-      code.path
+      inits.map(materializer.materialize(_).toString) ++ libs.map(
+          dep => materializer.materialize(dep.lib).toString) :+ code.path
     }
     val page = htmlPage(jsFiles)
```
